ygData.subject: Re : [neat] Musings On Lessons Learned From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Â Agree, BlindBuilder is a nice case of compact encoding does not means good encoding , for the reasons you mentionned. Modules are the way to go,

---655678339-1117704007-1321919759=:19450
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,
=C2=A0Agree, BlindBuilder is a nice case of "compact encoding does not =
means good encoding", for the reasons you mentionned. Modules are the way t=
o go, *BUT*... Most of time, when we say modules, it's some part of the gen=
otype which is taken and grafted somewhere else, verbatim. This is the leve=
l 0 of modularity, it makes tons of assumptions. Assumption that your probl=
em is nice enough to be trivially decomposible into subproblems solveable b=
y subpart of genotypes. Assumption that your problem is nice enough to pave=
 the road for you, miraculy making the right modules to appear in the right=
 order. Yes, with an optimization which is mostly a a biased random walk...=
 I can go on long of that, but, well, let's remove that dust on my PhD thes=
is and link it here (http://www.marmakoide.org/download/publications/adever=
t-phd-thesis.pdf), and invite you to read from page 21, section 1.3.3, to t=
he end of Chapter 1, which is a good summary of my views on modularity, wit=
h
 of course credit for my PhD advisors, Vishnu bless them ^^

=C2=A0
Dr. D=
evert Alexandre
Lecturer at School Of Software Engineering of USTC
166 Rena=
i Road, Dushu Lake Higher Education Town
Suzhou Industrial Park,
Suzhou, Ji=
angsu, People Republic of China


________________________________
 De=C2=
=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@...>
=C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Envoy=
=C3=A9 le : Mardi 22 Novembre 2011 3h18
Objet=C2=A0: [neat] Musings On Less=
ons Learned From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
 

=C2=A0=
 
Alex,
Your prior work associated w/ BlindBuilder I believe is informative=
 and applicable to possible updates to NEAT and indirect encodings in gener=
al. The growing disruptive impact of construction operators as the size of =
the construction plan increases, seemly undercuts the benefit of compact na=
ture of the approach, and also illustrates a fundamental strength and weakn=
ess of NEAT. NEAT, starting from minimal size, mitigates the disruptive nat=
ure of various operators at the beginning allowing for more effective use o=
f computational resources for growing of the organism in a profitable porti=
on of the design space. But as organism size increases, the growing disrupt=
ive impact of some operators, and where they are applied, increasingly bog =
down further progress.
In the context of BlindBuilder, two examples are use=
ful:
1) Bridge: The concept of a bridge is simple and straight forward. Fro=
m a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single element of ap=
propriate size and orientation. While the size of the construction plan is =
vastly different based upon the characteristics of the formative elements, =
though the concept is still simple, the disruptive impact of various operat=
ors on form, fit, function and convergence is also vastly different.
2) Wal=
l: Also, the concept of a wall is simple and straight forward. And again fr=
om a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single element of a=
ppropriate size and orientation. The same comments also apply regarding con=
struction plan size and associated disruptive impact of construction operat=
ors.
The point being, that the sensitivity of the concept should not be sub=
ject to the scale of the formative elements, but rather the suitability of =
the formulation to the objectives of the concept. In the construction conte=
xt, this is more straight forward. The overall objective is composed of a r=
elatively few well known concepts taken together in some relative orientati=
ons WRT each other (i.e. a house can be composed of four orthogonal walls a=
nd a roof). The construction operators should be confined to refinement of =
suitability of the formative elements and their orientations taken together=
 WRT the individual concept, guided by concept specific operator selection =
criteria (i.e. semi-separable multi-subobjectives).
Of course, in the gener=
al case, the identification of concepts is not as straight forward. But eff=
orts to identify reusable genetic material snippets would most likely quali=
fy as identification of concepts, and would thus likely benefit from: a) pa=
rtitioning of the genome for application of operators, and b) application o=
f concept specific operator selection WRT concept suitability for the curre=
nt overall objective.

Andy


 
---655678339-1117704007-1321919759=:19450
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

rt of the genotype which is taken and grafted somewhere else, verbatim. Thi=
s is the level 0 of modularity, it makes tons of assumptions. Assumption th=
at your problem is nice enough to be trivially decomposible into subproblem=
s solveable by subpart of genotypes. Assumption that your problem is nice e=
nough to pave the road for you, miraculy making the right modules to appear=

      <div>Alex,<br>
     Your prior work associated w/ Bl=
indBuilder I believe is informative and applicable to possible updates to N=
EAT and indirect encodings in general. The growing disruptive impact of con=
struction operators as the size of the construction plan increases, seemly =
undercuts the benefit of compact nature of the approach, and also illustrat=
es a fundamental strength and weakness of NEAT. NEAT, starting from minimal=
 size, mitigates the disruptive nature of various operators at the beginnin=
g allowing for more effective use of computational resources for growing of=
 the organism in a profitable portion of the design space. But as organism =
size increases, the growing disruptive impact of some operators, and where =
they are applied, increasingly bog down further progress.<br>
     In the c=
ontext of BlindBuilder, two examples are useful:<br>
1) Bridge: The concept=
 of a bridge is simple and straight forward. From a construction perspectiv=
e, could be achieved with a single element of appropriate size and orientat=
ion. While the size of the construction plan is vastly different based upon=
 the characteristics of the formative elements, though the concept is still=
 simple, the disruptive impact of various operators on form, fit, function =
and convergence is also vastly different.<br>
2) Wall: Also, the concept of=
 a wall is simple and straight forward. And again from a construction persp=
ective, could be achieved with a single element of appropriate size and ori=
entation. The same comments also apply regarding construction plan size and=
 associated disruptive impact of construction operators.<br>
     The point=
 being, that the sensitivity of the concept should not be subject to the sc=
ale of the formative elements, but rather the suitability of the formulatio=
n to the objectives of the concept. In the construction context, this is mo=
re straight forward. The overall objective is composed of a relatively few =
well known concepts taken together in some relative orientations WRT each o=
ther (i.e. a house can be composed of four orthogonal walls and a roof). Th=
e construction operators should be confined to refinement of suitability of=
 the formative elements and their orientations taken together WRT the indiv=
idual concept, guided by concept specific operator selection criteria (i.e.=
 semi-separable multi-subobjectives).<br>
    Of course, in the general cas=
e, the identification of concepts is not as straight forward. But efforts t=
o identify reusable genetic material snippets would most likely qualify as =
identification of concepts, and would thus likely benefit from: a) partitio=
ning of the genome for application of operators, and b) application of conc=
ept specific operator selection WRT concept suitability for the current ove=
rall objective.<br>
<br>
Andy<br>
<br>
</div>
